conversation.content: My roommate just told me she's moving out next month with zero warning.
Oh god, that's the worst feeling in the world. I remember when my roommate did that to me, left me completely stranded with double rent and this crushing sense of betrayal.
She said it was [confused] sudden but necessary. Whatever that means.
Yeah, necessary for her, right? I mean, people always, you know, justify their selfish decisions with vague words like that, basically leaving you to pick up all the pieces.
I guess I'm just, um, worried about finding someone new so, like, quickly.
Finding a decent roommate is literally impossible these days. Everyone's either a complete slob or has some bizarre quirk that makes them unbearable to live with, trust me.
Well, maybe I could, er, try living alone? I mean, it's just that the rent is, anyway, pretty steep.
Living alone sounds [very loudly] great until you're eating ramen for the third week straight because rent consumed your entire paycheck and then some.
There must be some good roommate options out there somewhere.

Oh honey, I've been through, [quickly] like, seven roommates in five years, and honestly, each one was worse than the last—the stealing food, the overnight guests, you know, the passive aggressive notes.
That sounds, um, [whispering] exhausting. Maybe I should, actually, just move back with my parents for a while.
Moving back home? God, that's basically, er, admitting defeat, isn't it? I did it once and, you know, my mom treated me like I was sixteen again, honestly, with curfews and everything.
Why does everything [monotone] have to be so complicated?
Because that's life, and it only gets worse from here. Wait until you're dealing with mortgages and property taxes and homeowner associations breathing down your neck about grass height.
You're really not, [loudly] uhh, helping with my anxiety here! The thing is, I need, well, actual solutions.
Solutions? Here's your [furious] solution: accept that people will always disappoint you, plan for the worst case scenario, and never, ever trust anyone who says they're reliable.
That's incredibly dark. Are you okay?
Am I okay? No one's okay, we're all just pretending while everything falls apart around us, but at least we can be miserable together, right?
I think, hmm, I'm going to, actually, call my sister instead. She's, er, usually more optimistic about these things.
Your sister, really? Well, okay so, when her advice fails and you realize I was, uhh, right all along, you know where to find me—drowning in my own, basically, realistic worldview.
